timeline.body: What is the -1 here? Would it be readable to follow the terminology of the modbus binding: "address" word would be used to refer zero based indices
timeline.bodyText: What is the -1 here? Would it be readable to follow the terminology of the modbus binding: "address" word would be used to refer zero based indices
timeline.bodyHTML: What is the -1 here? Would it be readable to follow the terminology of the modbus binding: "address" word would be used to refer zero based indices
timeline.author: ssalonen

replies.bodyText:
I'm a bit confused, too. The documentation states "In accordance with the Modbus protocol, a register R is numbered as R - 1 when transmitted." page 5 https://www.meterbuy.com/fileadmin/user_upload/Data_sheets/120102_SAIA_-_Data_sheet_26-529_EN_DS_Energy-Meter-ALD1-with-Modbus.pdf
Is this common to Modbus devices?
replies.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
In modbus binding terminology the register address refers to the address number on the wire, i.e. R-1.
This is typical source of confusion with Modbus. I even added section in the documentation clarifying the topic: https://www.openhab.org/addons/bindings/modbus/#comment-on-addressing
replies.author: ssalonen

replies.bodyText: I wasn't aware of this fine difference in wording. Changed it to FIRST_READ_REGISTER.
replies.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
I would have suggested to keep everything zero based, similar to the other bindings 😅...adding simply a comment referencing device manual
I think this is OK as well but perhaps good to add comment for posterity that this is 1-based register number, not the zero based address that goes on the wire.
Also note the same naming issue with channel definitions.
replies.author: ssalonen

replies.bodyText: Actually I always use zero-based numbers where possible, but my goal here was to use the same numbers in the constants as in the device's documentation. I added a comment and changed the wording in the enum.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.body: Unnecessary? You could construct QuantityType using the DecimalType without intermediate conversion to float
timeline.bodyText: Unnecessary? You could construct QuantityType using the DecimalType without intermediate conversion to float
timeline.bodyHTML: Unnecessary? You could construct QuantityType using the DecimalType without intermediate conversion to float
timeline.author: ssalonen

replies.bodyText: I need to apply a multiplier before converting it to QuantityType. Do you have a suggestion?
replies.author: fwolter

+import org.openhab.io.transport.modbus.ModbusConstants;
+import org.openhab.io.transport.modbus.ModbusConstants.ValueType;
+
+/**
+ * The {@link ALD1Registers} is responsible for defining Modbus registers and their units.
+ *
+ * @author Fabian Wolter - Initial contribution
+ */
+@NonNullByDefault
+public enum ALD1Registers {
+    TOTAL_ENERGY(0.01f, 28, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR),
+    PARTIAL_ENERGY(0.01f, 30, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR),
+    FEEDING_BACK_ENERGY(0.01f, 30, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR),

replies.bodyText: They are for distinct Thing types. I added a comment.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.message:
Incorporate review feedback #1

Signed-off-by: Fabian Wolter <github@fabian-wolter.de>

timeline.body:
Would this work?

```suggestion
                        .map(decimalState -> new QuantityType(decimalState.toBigDecimal().multiply(new BigDecimal(multiplier)), channel.getUnit()))
```

It's a minor cosmetic change to the original but avoids floating point conversions.
timeline.bodyText:
Would this work?
  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                                    .map(DecimalType::floatValue)
          
          
            
                                    .map(v -> QuantityType.valueOf(v * channel.getMultiplier(), channel.getUnit()))
          
          
            
                                    .map(decimalState -> new QuantityType(decimalState.toBigDecimal().multiply(new BigDecimal(multiplier)), channel.getUnit()))
          
      
    
    
  

It's a minor cosmetic change to the original but avoids floating point conversions.
timeline.bodyHTML:
Would this work?

Suggested change
.map(DecimalType::floatValue)
.map(v -> QuantityType.valueOf(v * channel.getMultiplier(), channel.getUnit()))
.map(decimalState -> new QuantityType(decimalState.toBigDecimal().multiply(new BigDecimal(multiplier)), channel.getUnit()))

It's a minor cosmetic change to the original but avoids floating point conversions.
timeline.author: ssalonen

replies.bodyText: Yes, I'm staying in the BigDecimal domain, now.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
TOTAL_ENERGY(0.01f, 28, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR),
PARTIAL_ENERGY(0.01f, 30, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR), // only unidirectional meters
FEEDING_BACK_ENERGY(0.01f, 30, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR), // only bidirectional meters
VOLTAGE(1, 36, UINT16, SmartHomeUnits.VOLT),
CURRENT(0.1f, 37, UINT16, SmartHomeUnits.AMPERE),
ACTIVE_POWER(10, 38, INT16, SmartHomeUnits.WATT),
REACTIVE_POWER(10, 39, INT16, SmartHomeUnits.VAR),
POWER_FACTOR(0.01f, 40, UINT16, SmartHomeUnits.ONE);
private BigDecimal multiplier;
private int registerAddress;
private ModbusConstants.ValueType type;
private Unit<?> unit;
private ALD1Registers(float multiplier, int registerAddress, ValueType type, Unit<?> unit) {
this.multiplier = new BigDecimal(multiplier);
TOTAL_ENERGY("0.01", 28, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR),
PARTIAL_ENERGY("0.01", 30, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR), // only unidirectional meters
FEEDING_BACK_ENERGY("0.01", 30, UINT32, SmartHomeUnits.KILOWATT_HOUR), // only bidirectional meters
VOLTAGE("1", 36, UINT16, SmartHomeUnits.VOLT),
CURRENT("0.1", 37, UINT16, SmartHomeUnits.AMPERE),
ACTIVE_POWER("10", 38, INT16, SmartHomeUnits.WATT),
REACTIVE_POWER("10", 39, INT16, SmartHomeUnits.VAR),
POWER_FACTOR("0.01", 40, UINT16, SmartHomeUnits.ONE);
private BigDecimal multiplier;
private int registerAddress;
private ModbusConstants.ValueType type;
private Unit<?> unit;
private ALD1Registers(String multiplier, int registerAddress, ValueType type, Unit<?> unit) {
this.multiplier = new BigDecimal(multiplier);

Just a cosmetic suggestion

With this change you would have "neat" finite numbers since big decimal operate in 10-base. See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7408566/java-double-value-0-01-changes-to-0-009999999999999787

Feel free to ignore this comment :)
timeline.author: ssalonen

replies.bodyText: I understand, but it seems more odd to me to have these numeric constants as strings...
replies.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
Yup.. No way around the strings really if we want stay fully in BigDecimal domain.
As said, feel free to ignore this comment, makes little practical difference really
replies.author: ssalonen
